issues.text: Whether the defendants by their conduct have waived the objection as to the territorial jurisdiction of the Cochin Court

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the plaintiff further submitted that, as a matter of fact, the defendants by their conduct have waived the objection. Though this submission found favour with the High Court, we are unable to accept it. If the defendant allows the trial Court to proceed to judgment without raising the objection as to the place of suing and takes the chance of a verdict in his favour, he clearly waives the objection

issues.text: Whether filing the application under s.34 and appeal under s.39 of the Arbitration Act concedes that the Cochin Court had jurisdiction to try the suit in view of the definition of 'Court' in s.2(c)

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that the effect of ss. 2 c , 34 and 39 of the Indian Arbitration Act was that by filing the appeal under s. 39 against the order of the Cochin Court refusing to stay the suit, the defendants must be deemed to have conceded that the Cochin Court was a Court having jurisdiction to try the suit.

issues.text: Whether the defendants are precluded under s.21 CPC from raising the territorial jurisdiction objection in the appellate court without alleging or proving a subsequent failure of justice

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the plaintiff also submitted that the defendants -having neither alleged nor proved that there has been a failure of justice in consequence of the order of the High Court, they are precluded by S. 21 of the Code from raising this objection in this Court. We think that this contention has no force.

holdings.text: As a general rule, neither consent nor waiver nor acquiescence can confer jurisdiction upon a Court otherwise incompetent to try the suit, but s. 21 CPC provides an exception for defect as to place of suing which may be waived.

holdings.text: An application under s. 34 of the Arbitration Act to the court before which the suit is pending is in no way a recognition that the court has jurisdiction to try the suit, nor does an appeal under s. 39 have that effect.

precedents.citation: Seth Hira Lal Patni v. Sri Kali Nath

anchor.surface_text: Seth Hira Lal Patni v. Sri Kali Nath.  1

precedents.case_name: Seth Hira Lal Patni v. Sri Kali Nath
precedents.cited_proposition: independently of s. 21, the defendant may waive the objection as to place of suing and may be subsequently precluded from taking it

precedents.citation: Kiran Singh and others Chaman Paswan and others

anchor.surface_text: Kiran Singh and others Chaman Paswan and others 2 thus  1  1955 1 S.C.R. 117, 122.  2  1955 1 S.C.R. 117,122. .lm15 The policy underlying sections 21 and 99 of the Civil Procedure Code and section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act is the same, namely, that when a case had been tried by a Court on the merits and judgment rendered, it should number be liable to be reversed purely on technical grounds, unless it had resulted in a failure of justice, and the policy of the Legislature has been to treat objections to jurisdiction both territorial and pecuniary as technical and number open to companysideration by an appellate Court, unless there has been a prejudice on the merits.

precedents.cited_proposition: objections to territorial or pecuniary jurisdiction are technical and not open to consideration in appellate court unless there has been a failure of justice after trial on merits
precedents.cited_holding: The policy underlying sections 21 and 99 of the Civil Procedure Code and section 11 of the Suits Valuation Act is the same, namely, that when a case had been tried by a Court on the merits and judgment rendered, it should number be liable to be reversed purely on technical grounds, unless it had resulted in a failure of justice, and the policy of the Legislature has been to treat objections to jurisdiction both territorial and pecuniary as technical and number open to companysideration by an appellate Court, unless there has been a prejudice on the merits.
